data.title: Task switching on Windows is slow
data.body:
When switching the active window with Alt-Ctrl, it often happens that nothing happens. This is because I'm used to task switching happen fast (instantly), but with Atom, it happens is that there is often maybe a 0.3 - 0.5 second delay until the "tasks dialog" (the dialog that contains task icons) appears.

So, in normal use switching task feels very unrealible - the task isn't often switched at all, since the dialog didn't appear fast enough.

Not sure if there is a fix for this or if this is because of the runtime used. Using Win 7 64-bit.

data.body:
[atom.pdf](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/54433/atom.pdf)
(I tried uploading a .log, but Github doesn't allow that)

Anyway, I hope this gets fixed. I love Atom!

data.title: SuSE 13.1 / KDE Atom Window is always on Top
data.body:
I just installed 1.2.4 via rpm in my Suse 13.1 Installation.
This error also occurs in the current beta-version.

The Atom-Window is always "on top" and hides everything benath it. Klicking on other windows / switching to other screens will always have the atom window on top.
Only way to minimize it is via the standard minimize controls, but the normal window behavior on loosing focus is not working.

Window has Focus:
![normal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1115563/11650872/d7d3ebe8-9d8c-11e5-8780-9e90393a1b8a.PNG)

Other Window has Focus. Atom Editor is "on top" and has lost the windows decoration
![otherwindow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1115563/11650877/db7ee7ac-9d8c-11e5-9131-beec8885dd29.PNG)

The most annoying part is, that the main window also hides all other dialogs. And often you don't know why the gui is not reacting:
After moving away the main Window:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1115563/11650933/62adebc4-9d8d-11e5-8f68-6c6480da401d.png)

data.title: Deserialize untitled editors
data.body:
Depends on https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/116.
Fixes #942.

Our serialization code already supported saving state for untitled `TextBuffer` instances, but the problem was that we used the file's path to identify and search for buffers in `TokenizedBuffer` and `atom.project`. This PR changes it so that, in addition to paths, we can make use of a uniquely generated id for each `TextBuffer`.

If the `TokenizedBuffer`'s state has a buffer path, we deserialize it exactly as before. Otherwise, we try to search by buffer id among all the project's buffers. It might be tempting to use IDs even when we have a path, but it still seems quite reasonable to just use them as a fallback for two potential problems:
1. Possible weird mismatches or false duplicates (e.g. two buffers have the same path, but different IDs)
2. Even if a buffer is not present in `atom.project`, we still want re-open a buffer at that location when deserializing a `TokenizedBuffer` (I am not sure we have any guarantee that this never happens).

Feedback welcome! :balloon: 

/cc: @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld @atom/feedback

data.title: Cursor doesn't jump to line without column number
data.body: Ctrl + G: "Enter a line row:column to go to". Ideally if I don't enter a column number and only a row number, it should go to the first column. But it doesn't. This is a usability issue and is up to the Atom team to decide. I just think it's one less keystroke if it's implemented. I say one keystroke, since entering a colon without the column number works as well. I'm using V 1.2.0 on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.

data.title: Golang syntax highlighting multiline strings in var block not highlighted
data.body:
If you have a multiline string in `var` section, it is not highlighted as string. Here is screenshot  with simple example:

![strings_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2859912/11618687/fbd17380-9cbf-11e5-83b9-40593f1a146a.png)

Scopes shown for every `string` entry from top to bottom. This bug reproduced with all string delimeters (`'`, `"`, `)

Atom version: 1.2.4

data.title: When opening single file the project folder is the file instead of folder above file
data.body:
### Steps to reproduce:
1. Remove all project folders.
2. Open a file via: Right click open in atom, Open a file dialog in atom, opening file via command line.
### Observed behavior:

Atom shows the project folder as the file that was opened.
### Expected behavior:

Atom selects the folder above the file and uses it as the project folder.
### Example

Opened file ~/path/index.html
Atom shows index.html as the project folder.
Atom should show ~/path as the project folder.
### Environment

Atom 1.2.4 (Latest as of 07/12/2015
Windows 8.1 64bit
Reproduced in safe mode (atom --safe)

data.title: Ability to configure find/search to be like gedit
data.body:
Gedit 3 has the most convenient find feature I've ever used.
- Ctrl-f brings up a very tiny input box in the top right which doesn't obscure any code.
- Results are shown to you as you start typing, without having to hit enter.
- Down/up arrows select the next/previous results.
- Enter exits the search, leaving the current result selected.
- Esc exits the search but puts you back where you started before searching.

I've managed to get down/up arrows working, but there doesn't seem to be a way to exit find and replace with anything other than hitting esc. Furthermore, recording the state before the search begins is beyond simple keymapping.

``` cson
'.find-and-replace, .project-find, .project-find .results-view':
  'up': 'find-and-replace:show-previous'
  'down': 'find-and-replace:confirm'
```

Are these enter/esc actions something that could make it into the core find-and-replace?

data.title: Atom QuickLook plugin on OS X
data.body:
Some apps bundle a QuickLook plugin (`.qlgenerator`) inside a `.app/Contents/Library/QuickLook` folder which OS X will load automatically.

It would be _really_ cool if Atom came with a QL plugin to render previews/thumbnails using the same syntax highlighting/theme as the editor.

I'd be happy to help out with this, but not quite sure how to go about it…

data.title: Boot up Error for Atom 1.2.4 for Windows 10
data.body:
**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Open up Atom
2. Watch error

**Expected behavior:**

Expected the Editor to open with a blank page to insert code.

**Observed behavior:**

Editor opens and only developer tools appears at the bottom highlighting an error.

**Screenshots and GIFs**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335441/11613419/70416bd4-9c17-11e5-83a1-1415280bb172.png)

**Atom version:**  1.2.4
**OS and version:** Window 10

**Installed packages:**

meteor-api
meteor-helper

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: Yes - Just using started this version. But it is reproduced with Verion 1.3.0 - beta 6 and 1.2.3
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes

data.title: On close, "don't save all"
data.body: Would be cool if there was an "apply to all" here. Sometimes my mounted share gets disconnected and Atom thinks all the files need to be "saved" because they're no longer there.

data.title: Hide all "Open Your ..." menu items behind a single one
data.body:
Could we please combine all of those items behind a single menu item called `Open Your ...`, `Open Your` or `Modifications`? If you ask me, that would be a lot better than repeating "Open Your" over and over again.

The new item should then contain "Config", "Init Script", "Keymap", "Snippets" and "Stylesheet".

![menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6170607/11608038/a397c1f4-9b5e-11e5-9c2b-2cd2aca4bc9d.png)

data.title: UI bug in open file
data.body: When i open file, at window left-bottom, should not appear "Hide extension". Platform is Mac OS X. Atom version is 1.2.4.

data.title: save config.cson in alphabetic order
data.body:
Currently the `config.cson` is being written in semi-random order (insertion order of the object properties). That makes it pretty difficult so visually find certain options or compare two `config.cson` files from different atom installations. Especially after changing configuration options back and forth the same set of config values results in a very different file.

By ordering the object properties alphabetically the output of that file becomes deterministic. The same configuration results in the same file. And diffing or comparing changes becomes much easier.
- The first commit only contains the new spec (which obviously fails without any other changes):

```
it writes properties in alphabetical order
    Expected [ 'foo', 'bar', 'baz' ] to equal [ 'bar', 'baz', 'foo' ]. (spec/config-spec.coffee:697:29)
    Expected [ 'foo', 'bar' ] to equal [ 'bar', 'foo' ]. (spec/config-spec.coffee:700:29)
```
- The second commit updates the save function to store the data with a deterministic order.

data.title: Don’t force DOM updates in LinesYardstick
data.body:
In contemplating a radically different approach to rendering lines based on the new display layers, @maxbrunsfeld and I got a bit confused following the logic of editor DOM updates. We think it will be easier to follow if the `LinesYardstick` never forces a DOM update, but instead requires all lines being measured to be on the DOM as part of its contract.

That means we break `TextEditorComponent.updateSync` into two explicit pre-measurement and post-measurement phases directly in the component so it's more explicit to see, then add visibility checks and synchronous updates on any of the exposed measurement methods on the component.

This might have conflicts with block decorations, but it's going to make it easier for us to maneuver as we render via the `DisplayLayer`'s `TokenIterator` instead of from `TokenizedLines`.

data.title: at (@) keyboard shortcut does not work on mac with swiss german keyboard layout
data.body: In the swiss german mac keyboard layout, the at (@) sign is made using the `ALT-G` keyboard shortcut. In atom, this does not work, which makes it very inconvenient to code.

data.title: Atom remove Projects folder when opening files from context menu
data.body: Atom keep removing my projects folder whenever i tried to open a files through context menu "Open with Atom" or by double clicking the file (associated with Atom, as in Atom is the default program for the particular file format).
